awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering.  The fellowships advance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future.  This fellowship to Sharri Zamore supports research to understand neural control of aerodynamic stability in flying snakes.  The host institution is Virginia Tech, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jake Socha.  In addition to a new understanding of a unique form of animal flight, this research promises to contribute to other fields beyond biology, such as bio-inspired robotics.  The fellowship includes a teaching plan for creating a new course in neural control and dynamics and focuses on outreach, particularly via social media. This research offers an opportunity for working with students of all ages and backgrounds and has great potential far-reaching impact through new developments of educational material.  Research training objectives include mastering techniques of computational modeling, development and implementation of wireless sensors, and reconstruction and analysis of 3-D trajectories.

Flying snakes (Chrysopelea sp.¬) are capable of gliding despite having a cylindrical shape and no specialized appendages (such as flaps or wings), and therefore offer a unique window into understanding the mechanics of gliding flight. During glides, these snakes undulate in a complex three-dimensional pattern, which suggests that gliding stability may require integration of sensory input (such as vision and balance) and muscular output for control. This research examines responses to unexpected disturbances in vision and displacement using air gusts. How these disturbances affect glide performance enables the prediction of how stability of a gliding cylindrical body can be achieved. This research provides the first insights into the sensorimotor control mechanisms that enable stable gliding by flying snakes.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: BIO MINORITY POSTDOC RESEARCH FELLOW PGM

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to elucidate underlying controls in locomotion in a rarely-studied organism, the paradise tree snake (Chrysopelea paradisi). C. paradisi is an adept glider, able to produce the same glide ratios (2.2 ± 1.1 Lift:Drag)1 in flight as flying squirrel (1.98)2 and flying squirrels (1.87 ± 0.04)3. This study provides in-depth characterization of visual systems, little-studied in any gliding organism, let alone snakes.

This project's two arms focused on characterizing the visual system in C. paradisi and how C. paradisi may use visual cues in locomotion. The study yielded two major findings:

  1. We found that C. paradisi has broad spatial and temporal tuning, with highest-strength of response (gain) seen at 46.07 ± 11.08 Hz  with a temporal frequency cut off that is over 100 Hz, and 2.89 ± 0.16 cycles per degree (cpd), with a spatial frequency cut off around 4 cpd. To translate this to relatable values, C. paradisi can potentially process visual information about twice as fast as humans, who have a peak sensitivity at 15-20 Hz and a cutoff around 60 Hz 2. C. paradisi would also be legally blind, as their visual acuity is about the same as a human with 20/200 vision. 
    We also found several classifications of visual behaviors and determined  volumetric field of vision using virtual inverse perimetry.     
  2. We designed and used an immersive visual VR arena to successfully replicate the physical (or "analog") test conditions used to characterize snake vision. This digital version elicited the same visual reflex (optokinetic nystagmus) and, when introduced in a closed-loop setting (snake head movement controls the virtual camera position and direction), we were able to confirm the behavioral function of optokinetic nystagmus: to hold a visual scene steady on the retina. This finding was evidenced by the rotating scene held still when the snake elicited a smooth pursuit, which matched the rotation of the scene, creating a fixed instead of moving stimulus.

This project's data-driven results are only a portion of its success. Methodologies that streamline and facilitate visual stimulus generation and behavioral evaluation were also produced in this project.

  1.  Optomotor Drum Setup - While a canonical methodology, optomotor drums are difficult to design, purchase and build. Our design is affordable and designed with easy-to-find, low cost parts.
  2. Digital Reverse Perimetry - By digitizing the snake head with a laser scanner, and reconstructing it with CAD software, we were able to map its visual field, using projected beams (rays) and identifying the surface (eye or face) upon which the beam landed first. By systematically measuring points along an encompassing sphere, we were able to reconstruct the putative field of vision. The digitized version of inverse perimetry has been rarely used, but provides an easy and accessible means of noninvasive measure of field of vision.
  3. Immersive VR Arena -  Another often-inaccessible tool, VR is valued for its ability to create closed looped behavioral systems (where the organism?s movements influences the virtual scene), and its growing use in educational formats. This arena design uses open source software, describes system requirements based on animal features, making it adaptable for a number of research and educational purposes. The programs were developed using open source platforms (Unity, Blender, Python), with all code, packages and assets available for free. Walkthroughs, documentation and updates are currently in development.

By following my model of using gaming development platforms to create digital reconstructions and virtual scenes, scientists will also be able to easily produce accessible content for the public. A reconstructed view or scene can be created using the same tools to measure the system, given a clear, user-interpretable experiential description of vision in other organisms.

The design, components and measurements have been published in Journal of Integrative and Comparative Biology (2020). The repository for the virtual arena can be found on Github (VizSciVR).

 

 

References Cited

  1. John J. Socha, Tony O'Dempsey, Michael LaBarbera; A 3-D kinematic analysis of gliding in a flying snake, Chrysopelea paradisi. J Exp Biol 15 May 2005; 208 (10): 1817?1833. doi: https://doi.org/10.1242/jeb.01579
  2. Karl Vernes, Gliding Performance of the Northern Flying Squirrel (Glaucomys Sabrinus) in Mature Mixed Forest of Eastern Canada, Journal of Mammalogy, Volume 82, Issue 4, November 2001, Pages 1026?1033, https://doi.org/10.1644/1545-1542(2001)082<1026:GPOTNF>2.0.CO;2
  3. Jackson, S.M. (2000), Glide angle in the genus Petaurus and a review of gliding in mammals. Mammal Review, 30: 9-30. https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1365-2907.2000.00056.x
  4. Kalloniatis M, Luu C. Temporal Resolution. 2005 May 1 [Updated 2007 Jun 5]. In: Kolb H, Fernandez E, Nelson R, editors. Webvision: The Organization of the Retina and Visual System [Internet]. Salt Lake City (UT): University of Utah Health Sciences Center; 1995-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK11559/

Last Modified: 05/01/2022
Modified by: Sharri Zamore

Images (1 of )
  • C. paradisi on a branch. Courtesy of Jake Socha
    Jake Socha
    Copyrighted
    Sharri Zamore
    C. paradisi on a branch
  • A. Acrylic paint was used to protect and improve the quality of scan of the eye. B. The 3D reconstructed head. C. Inverse Perimetry using ray casting. A sweep of positions (blue) was used at every vertex of an encompassing sphere. If one or both eyes were hit first, it was indicated (yellow).
    Shaz Zamoer
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sharri Zamore
    Inverse perrimetry methods: animal preparation, 3D model of head and representation of virtual ray casting with reconstructed head
  • We found that in two individuals of C. paradisi have a wide azimuthal range of view (around 270�), and binocular range that is biased upward. The binocular range is larger in males, who are generally smaller than females.
    Shaz Zamore
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sharri Zamore
    Field of vision in C. paradisi - 3D representation, and 2D projections (horizontal and vertical)
  • A. (Left) A schematic diagram of the VR system. A optically clear acrylic drum (blue) was placed on an air table (brown). (Right) A CAD arena render. The snake's head (inset) was tracked with an overhead camera, which updated the virtual camera.B. The virtual optokinetic drum scene and view.
    Shaz Zamore
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sharri Zamore
    The Immersive Visual VR Arena (IVVA) - a schematic diagam, 3D CAD rendering, and example virtual scene & view

This research project aimed to elucidate underlying controls in locomotion in a rarely-studied organism, the paradise tree snake (Chrysopelea paradisi). We found that C. paradisi has broad spatial and temporal tuning, with highest-strength of response (gain) seen at 46.07 ± 11.08 Hz  with a temporal frequency cut off that is over 100 Hz, and 2.89 ± 0.16 cycles per degree (cpd), with a spatial frequency cut off around 4 cpd. To translate this to relatable values, C. paradisi can potentially process visual information about twice as fast as humans, who have a peak sensitivity at 15-20 Hz and a cutoff around 60 Hz 2. C. paradisi would also be legally blind, as their visual acuity is about the same as a human with 20/200 vision.

Digital Reverse Perimetry - By digitizing the snake head with a laser scanner, and reconstructing it with CAD software, we were able to map its visual field, using projected beams (rays) and identifying the surface (eye or face) upon which the beam landed first. The design, components and measurements have been published in Journal of Integrative and Comparative Biology (2020). The repository for the virtual arena can be found on Github (VizSciVR).
